author: By Jennifer Medina
title: In South Texas, Hispanic Republicans Try to Cement the Party’s Gains
description: Conservative Hispanic leaders, especially women, are ascendant in the Rio Grande Valley, where Republicans are trying to forge lasting bonds with voters who swung sharply to the right in 2020.
content: McALLEN, Texas — The front door of the Hidalgo County Republican Party’s office is covered with photographs of high-profile politicians in the party: Gov. Greg Abbott, Senator John Cornyn and former President Donald J. Trump. Nearly all of them are white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Get Dressed With the Postal Service and Listen to Classical Music
description: This week, learn about the history of Cinco de Mayo, explore the future of America’s Chinatowns or make paper flowers.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jyoti Shelar
title: The chief medical officer at a Mumbai hospital, honored for her work to fight Covid, died with the disease.
description: Dr. Manisha Jadhav, the chief medical officer at the Group of Tuberculosis Hospitals in Mumbai, died on April 19 in a hospital in that city. She was 51. The cause was complications of Covid-19, her husband said.
content: Dr. Manisha Jadhav, the chief medical officer at the Group of Tuberculosis Hospitals in Mumbai, died on April 19 in a hospital in that city. She was 51. The cause was complications of Covid-19, her husband said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Once Aboard, We Noticed Some Groups of People Sticking Together’
description: A ride on the Circle Line, picking out produce and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: With Her Final Album, Rebecca Luker Bids a Fond Farewell
description: The much-loved Broadway soprano, who died in December, had one more miracle up her sleeve.
content: The last solo number on “All the Girls,” the new duo album from the sopranos Rebecca Luker and Sally Wilfert, is a piece of specialty material for Luker called “Not Funny.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassie Winslow
title: Surprise Mom With a Floral Cocktail
description: Flowers are magic. They are beautiful, uplifting and, when added to a drink, incredibly refreshing.
content: Flower bouquets have been go-to gifts on Mother’s Day for decades, as blooms celebrate love and admiration. But this year, honor the mothers in your life by making a floral libation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: In Anti-Ownership Protests, United Fans Rediscover Their Own Power
description: The protests, by Manchester United fans demanding the Glazer family sell the club, forced the postponement of a match after the stadium was stormed.
content: At the Lowry Hotel, Manchester United’s players could do nothing but sit and watch. Outside, hundreds of fans had gathered, blockading the buses scheduled to take them on the short trip to Old Trafford. They were supposed to depart at 3 p.m., local time. It came and went. The crowd did not disperse. Then 4 p.m. ticked by on the clock. Still no movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: In a First, Researchers Discover a Pregnant Egyptian Mummy
description: “It’s like finding a treasure trove while you are picking up mushrooms in a forest,” an archaeologist said. “We are overwhelmed with this discovery.”
content: An Egyptian mummy that for decades was thought to be a male priest was recently discovered to have been a pregnant woman, making it the first known case of its kind, scientists said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Maskless and Sweaty: Clubbing Returns to Britain for a Weekend
description: In Liverpool, people danced together at a warehouse party as part of a scientific trial of how and if social distancing can safely end.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — Around 3,000 clubbers were rammed up against each other inside a Liverpool warehouse on Friday night, waving their hands in the air to pounding techno music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Make a Card That Blooms
description: A card decorated with pop-up flowers can serve as a perfect spring greeting. (Just in case you forgot, Mother’s Day is around the corner.)
content: Coax your newspaper into three-dimensional flowers to make a sweet springy pop-up card for a special someone: mother, aunt, grandma, sister, friend, anyone! Once you learn this surprisingly simple technique for making cupped flowers, you can layer or tape them side-by-side to make different styles. Cut almond shapes and thin strips of newspaper for leaves and stems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Makes First Nighttime Splashdown With Astronauts Since 1968
description: Crew-1, which launched to the space station in November, left the space station in the capsule called Resilience.
content: In darkness, four astronauts splashed down early Sunday morning in the Gulf of Mexico near Panama City, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: How Can the Olympics Protect 78,000 Volunteers From the Coronavirus?
description: They are being offered little more than a couple of masks, some hand sanitizer and social-distancing guidance that may be hard to abide by.
content: TOKYO — For Olympic host cities, one of the keys to a successful Games is the army of volunteers who cheerfully perform a range of duties, like fetching water, driving Olympic vehicles, interpreting for athletes or carrying medals to ceremonies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Gunman Kills 2 at Wisconsin Casino
description: Police said officers killed the assailant in the shooting outside a casino and hotel complex in Green Bay.
content: A gunman killed two people at a Wisconsin casino late Saturday and seriously injured a third, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: $18 Million Refit of Colosseum Will Give Visitors a Gladiator’s View
description: The winning design for a new floor for the Roman landmark, planned to be ready for 2023, will cover the exposed subterranean chambers and reconnect “the thread of time.”
content: ROME — It is a view that gladiators would once have experienced as they prepared for mortal combat: staring into the banked crowds of the Colosseum, perhaps under the gaze of the mighty Roman emperor himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Saul Martinez
title: Denied a Season, Some Ivy League Athletes Craft a Baseball Gap Year
description: The Ivy League, unlike most Division I conferences, decided against spring sports. That has led some athletes, like baseball players at Brown, to find outside ways to train.
content: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Brown University’s baseball players returned to their Rhode Island campus in the dead of winter primarily because there was a sliver of hope for a season. Classes were remote, the athletic facilities were restricted and they had to quarantine for two weeks when they arrived in mid-January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: How a Miami School Became a Beacon for Anti-Vaxxers
description: Centner Academy barred teachers newly vaccinated against the coronavirus from being near students. Some parents threatened to withdraw their children. Others clamored to enroll.
content: MIAMI — A fifth-grade math and science teacher peddled a bogus conspiracy theory on Wednesday to students at Centner Academy, a private school in Miami, warning them that they should not hug parents who had been vaccinated against the coronavirus for more than five seconds because they might be exposed to harmful vaccine shedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jason Matthews, C.I.A. Officer Turned Novelist, Dies at 69
description: After 33 years at the agency, he turned out three well-received novels that included realistic details of espionage — and appearances by Vladimir Putin.
content: Jason Matthews, who after 33 years as a C.I.A. officer in Istanbul, Athens, Belgrade, Rome, Budapest and Hong Kong became a best-selling author of three spy thrillers, died on Wednesday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Is America a Racist Country?
description: The answer is “yes,” and that’s not a radical statement.
content: Last Sunday, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina added himself to the long list of Republicans who have denied the existence of systemic racism in this country. Graham said on “Fox New Sunday” that “our systems are not racist. America’s not a racist country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Marie Fazio
title: At Least 3 Die After Human-Smuggling Boat Hits Reef Near San Diego
description: Twenty-seven others were rescued and taken to hospitals after the 40-foot craft splintered in rough seas, the San Diego Fire-Rescue Department said.
content: At least three people died and more than two dozen others were hospitalized after an overcrowded boat being used to smuggle migrants broke apart on a reef off the coast of San Diego on Sunday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 3, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Got Rags? Weave a Rug
description: It’s easy to turn unwanted pieces of cloth into fun home décor.
content: After more than a year spent at home and with spring in full swing, you may be feeling the urge to brighten your space with a little redecorating. Enter rag rugs, floor covers made from scrap fabrics, which are an easy, low-budget craft that can cheer up any room using materials you probably already have at home. They have the added benefit of upcycling old textiles that may  otherwise end up in landfills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Biden’s Proposals Aim to Give Sturdier Support to the Middle Class
description: His message is that the private sector alone cannot provide security and comfort to the vast majority of Americans.
content: Perhaps the most striking difference between the middle class of 50 years ago and the middle class today is a loss of confidence — the confidence that you were doing better than your parents and that your children would do better than you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets Rally to Beat Phillies After Squandering Lead
description: A win over Philadelphia came with help from the umpires. The Yankees, meanwhile, got Jameson Taillon’s first win since 2019.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Michael Conforto hit a tiebreaking homer leading off the ninth inning and the Mets benefited from a very questionable call by the second base umpire Saturday night in a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Hogan and Jacoby Adeshei Carter
title: There’s No Classics ‘Catastrophe’ at Howard University
description: Our students will still be studying Plato and Aristotle, but we can't afford a whole department.
content: Cornel West and his co-author made a common mistake when they wrote a recent essay in The Washington Post chastising Howard University for eliminating its classics department. Reducing the decision to a “spiritual catastrophe,” they overlooked a deeper and more urgent problem: the financial constraints facing historically Black colleges and universities, and the inequality that underlies them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Means of Defense
description: Ross Trudeau brings back childhood memories.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ross Trudeau has become a valuable mentor in the crossword puzzle making community — if you are interested in getting started, his contact info is in his notes below — but, as I’m sure he would confirm, sometimes you just have to go it alone. Sometimes an idea is just yours, and you want to present it that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Plan for Paid Family Leave
description: Biden announced an ambitious — and expensive — plan to fund paid family leave, child care and higher education.
content: Good morning and happy May. Is anyone else itching for a vacation, or just a chance to go … elsewhere? Good news: If you’re vaccinated, you could escape to Europe (and help boost its ailing tourism industry) as soon as this summer. Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech news. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Indian Health Service Settles Dispute Over Care in New Mexico
description: The federal agency agreed to postpone for a year its proposal to cut service at a hospital serving 9,100 tribal citizens.
content: After a public outcry and a legal fight, the Indian Health Service has agreed to keep the emergency departments and inpatient care open for another year at a hospital in northwestern New Mexico serving 9,100 tribal citizens, settling at least temporarily a dispute that had become a flash point between tribal communities and the federal government over the quality and accessibility of health care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The virus is surging in Alaska’s interior, straining a Fairbanks hospital.
description: New cases have more than doubled in the past two weeks in the burough that includes the city, and the positivity rate had soared to about 10 percent.
content: Dr. Angelique Ramirez, the chief medical officer of the main health care system in Fairbanks, Alaska, started the monthly coronavirus briefing in April by saying that she thought March’s meeting would be the last. But amid a new surge of cases in the state, one of the country’s worst surges, Dr. Ramirez was blunt about her past assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
title: With India drowning in crisis, Modi’s party loses big in a key election.
description: One of India’s feistiest opposition parties cruised to victory in a crucial state elections in West Bengal on Sunday, dealing a blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a campaign held during a catastrophic Covid-19 surge.
content: One of India’s feistiest opposition parties cruised to victory in a crucial state elections in West Bengal on Sunday, dealing a blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a campaign held during a catastrophic Covid-19 surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynn Steger Strong
title: An Ambitious Novel Takes Flight
description: In “Great Circle,” Maggie Shipstead crosses centuries and time zones to deliver an epic story of women whose lives are up in the air.
content: GREAT CIRCLEBy Maggie Shipstead
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Has Online Retail’s Biggest Bully Returned?
description: Outraged customers of Eyeglassesdepot sound like the victims of a man who’s already spent years in prison for terrorizing consumers.
content: The worst online shopping experience of Samin Beringer’s life started with a Google search last fall for a pair of Chanel sunglasses. One of her top results was a site called Eyeglassesdepot, which promised to beat the price of any competitor. On Nov. 2, she placed an order with the company for $322.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Clubhouse App Creates Space for Open Talk in Middle East
description: The social networking app is booming in authoritarian countries, where users are speaking freely about otherwise taboo topics.
content: CAIRO — Faezeh Hashemi, the Iranian politician and daughter of a former president, is banned from speaking publicly in Iran. State television does not give her airtime. Conservative vigilantes have stormed her previous attempts to speak in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Don’t wait: Make Eric Kim’s sheet-pan bibimbap or kimchi jjiigae with ribs, which he adapted from his mother, Jean, soonest.
content: Good morning. Eric Kim has a lovely story in The Times about moving home to Atlanta to live with his mother during the pandemic, and how they cooked together and what he learned: an inheritance of kimchi and jjigaes. The lessons went both ways. When Eric’s mom tasted his sheet-pan bibimbap (above), she told him, “I’m never doing it the other way again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Moyn
title: What Kind of Fear Is Stopping Joe Biden?
description: A politics driven by threats from angry voters, domestic uprisings and foreign states will not break the American impasse.
content: Enthusiasm for President Biden’s ambition is rampant among progressives. In the first 100 days of his presidency, he has inspired premonitions of the second coming of Franklin Roosevelt. In his address to Congress last week, Mr. Biden himself invoked the parallel, “turning peril into possibility.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 9 Years After Tragedy, a Search for Remembrance
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 2, 2021.
content: “Everybody talks about how we’re this ‘strong’ and that ‘strong’ and ‘We will get past this,’ and ‘This isn’t who we are.’ Maybe it’s time for us to look at ourselves and say, ‘This is who we are. This is what happens to us in this country. This happens. And maybe we’re not strong, and maybe this town will be defined by this forever and ever and ever.’”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘He Wants to Save Classics From Whiteness. Can the Field Survive?’
description: Dan-el Padilla Peralta thinks classicists should knock ancient Greece and Rome off their pedestal — even if that means destroying their discipline.
content: For years, Dan-el Padilla Peralta, a Dominican-born teacher of classics at Princeton, has spoken openly about the harm caused by the discipline’s practitioners in the two millenniums since antiquity — the classical justifications of slavery, race science, colonialism, Nazism and other 20th-century fascisms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee and Lauren Hirsch
title: Verizon Near Deal to Sell Yahoo and AOL
description: In making the deal with the private equity firm Apollo, Verizon is acknowledging that it couldn’t compete with Google and Facebook for digital ads. Instead, it will concentrate on building a 5G network.
content: Verizon once saw media as the future, the linchpin of a strategy to give customers something they couldn’t get elsewhere at a time when all mobile offerings were essentially the same. It has a different vision for the future now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: This Spring, Get the Balls Rolling
description: In this era of social distancing, lawn games like croquet, badminton and horseshoes offer a great way to spend some time outside.
content: A year ago, when shelves dedicated to toilet paper and baking yeast yawned empty and respirator masks and hand sanitizer were sold out seemingly everywhere, shoppers in England encountered another shortage: croquet sets.But supplies have rebounded, and as leisure seekers everywhere should recognize, croquet and related lawn games — played outdoors and at a convenient distance — are reasonably safe alternatives to team sports or going to the gym.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Erin Griffith
title: Apple and Epic Head to Court Over Their Slices of the App Pie
description: Apple and Epic Games, maker of the wildly popular game Fortnite, square off on Monday in a trial that could decide how much control Apple can exert over the app economy.
content: One Friday last August, Tim Sweeney, a billionaire game developer, sent an email to a contact at Microsoft: “You’ll enjoy the upcoming fireworks show.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
title: Modi’s Party Loses a Key Election, Held Under the Cloud of Covid
description: The prime minister’s party lost big in West Bengal amid criticism that his mishandling of the pandemic had fueled a catastrophic surge of cases in India.
content: NEW DELHI — One of India’s feistiest opposition parties cruised to victory in state elections in West Bengal on Sunday, dealing a blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a campaign held during a catastrophic surge in Covid-19 infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: Some Dramatic Quarterback Successions Start at the N.F.L. Draft
description: If the draft last week revealed anything, it was that there’s no tactful way to replace a healthy starting quarterback.
content: Replacing a franchise quarterback is not as simple as drafting his successor. It’s more like selecting the heir to the throne of some ancient empire: full of drama, intrigue, careful diplomacy and the constant threat of open rebellion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: May 2, 2021
description: A note and corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 2, 2021.
content: An article on March 7 about Paul Rusesabagina, whose actions inspired the movie “Hotel Rwanda,” omitted a source’s connection to Paul Kagame, the president of Rwanda. Pierre-Richard Prosper was the lead attorney defending Kagame in a lawsuit filed in United States federal court in 2010. Prosper would not disclose whether he or his firm, Arent Fox, currently provides legal services to the government of Rwanda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: When The Times Didn’t Print on Sundays
description: The breakout of the Civil War created a huge demand for news and allowed The Times to vault over a taboo and put out a daily paper on Sundays.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Amid Signs of Trouble, Can MOCA Find Its Footing?
description: The last year was bumpy for this Los Angeles museum, with Covid-19, questions about diversity and a reorganization. But its director, Klaus Biesenbach, says, “every day is a chance to improve.”
content: LOS ANGELES — Klaus Biesenbach strutted through the Geffen Contemporary, the Museum of Contemporary Art’s warehouse exhibition space recently, stylish in his signature midnight blue suit and black ankle boots. Talking about plans to reopen on June 3 and recent building improvements he has made as director, he came across like a guy with his hands on the steering wheel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: India, Voting Rights, Kentucky Derby: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A political setback for Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
content: As India recorded 401,993 new coronavirus cases on Saturday, a global record, Prime Minister Narendra Modi failed to win a desperately wanted prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Pete Lammons, Who Helped the Jets Win ’69 Super Bowl, Dies at 77
description: After his football career, he bred racehorses and competed in professional fishing tournaments. He died after falling out of a boat in East Texas.
content: Pete Lammons, the tight end for the Jets team that stunned the pro football world with a victory over the Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, died on Thursday in a boating accident during a professional fishing tournament in East Texas. He was 77 and had been living in Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Gaffney
title: Take In a Concert Online
description: Virtually live performances are getting livelier (and bigger), with some great acts and multi-artist concerts to watch this month.
content: While many cities across the country are increasingly opening up, the state of entertainment remains bifurcated. Socially distanced indoor shows have returned to live-music venues like City Winery in New York, and Austin’s Nutty Brown Amphitheater, while NY PopsUp is offering a series of indoor and outdoor performances at locations across New York State, leading up to the eventual reopening of Broadway. (As part of the venture, Nathan Lane and Savion Glover were the first artists to grace a Broadway stage since last March, while Amy Schumer, Chris Rock and Hugh Jackman are scheduled for future events.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Jesus Jiménez
title: Boxer Charged in Killing of Pregnant Woman Found in Puerto Rican Lagoon
description: Félix Verdejo Sánchez, who competed at the 2012 Olympic Games, surrendered after the body of Keishla Rodríguez Ortiz was found near San Juan, the authorities said.
content: The Puerto Rican boxer Félix Verdejo Sánchez turned himself in to law enforcement officials on the island on Sunday evening and is facing charges of killing a pregnant woman whose body washed up in a lagoon on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Matthew Haag
title: ‘We’re Suffering’: How Remote Work Is Killing Manhattan’s Storefronts
description: Landlords cut small retailers a break on rent during the pandemic, but stores are still struggling because too few office workers and tourists have returned.
content: A big shift toward working from home is endangering hundreds of locally owned Manhattan storefronts that have been hanging on, waiting for life to return to the desolate streets of Midtown and the Financial District.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: As Body Cameras Become Commonplace, a Debate Over When to Release the Footage
description: The question of timing has become an unsettled new frontier of policymaking as the use of police body cameras is more the rule rather than the exception.
content: ELIZABETH CITY, N.C. — Ma’Khia Bryant had been dead only a few hours when the authorities in Columbus, Ohio, released body camera footage from the police officer who had shot and killed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Mercedes EQS Electric Sedan: The S Stands for Stunning
description: The automaker should be able to win back some customers who drifted to Tesla, and hold onto the Tesla-curious.
content: For half a century, the Mercedes-Benz S-class has been the brand’s flagship, hosting innovative technological, safety, design and engineering features that eventually trickle down through Mercedes’s lineup — and often throughout the auto industry as a whole. But starting 2012, Tesla arrived with a capital S of its own, and its Model S began to steal some swagger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Warns Biden Against ‘Hostile Policy’
description: An official said President Biden had made “a big blunder” by characterizing the North’s nuclear arsenal as a threat to the United States.
content: SEOUL — North Korea said on Sunday that President Biden had made “a big blunder” by calling its nuclear arsenal a threat last week, and it warned that the United States would face “a very grave situation” if it maintained its “hostile policy” toward Pyongyang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: ‘Donkey Hodie’ Adds a Fresh Face to Fred Rogers’s World. And a Mohawk.
description: The new PBS Kids series follows the spunky young granddaughter of a character from “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood” as she learns important lessons about facing life’s challenges.
content: The world of “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood” is far more associated with cozy cardigans and navy blue tennis shoes than with a spiky shock of magenta hair. But even Mister Rogers had a funny and funkier side, now re-emerging in a little yellow dynamo called Donkey Hodie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Love or Spycraft: What Landed an American Teacher in a Cuban Prison?
description: It was a romance steeped in international intrigue, and it landed Alina López Miyares in a Cuban prison. How much did she know about the web that entangled her?
content: MIAMI — A secret marriage. A cryptic phone call. And then, a flight to Cuba from which Alina López Miyares never returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Lucha Libre, Yoga, Dancing: Welcome to Mexico City’s Vaccination Sites
description: To calm Mexico City’s elderly, who were arriving “really scared” at vaccination sites, officials cued up the bands and masked wrestlers.
content: MEXICO CITY — Someone in a Charlie Brown costume frantically waves hello. A person dressed as a monkey pretends to take photos with a stuffed camera. An elderly man who just got his second shot of the Pfizer vaccine grabs a microphone and starts singing very loudly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Russian Attempts to Expand Sputnik Vaccine Set Off Discord in Europe
description: Political turmoil in Slovakia is an example of how Russia’s vaccine diplomacy, which has divided politicians across Europe, can have negative side effects for a recipient country.
content: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — When Slovakia’s prime minister welcomed a military aircraft carrying 200,000 doses of the Sputnik V vaccine from Russia in March, he posed proudly for photographs on the tarmac in front of crates stuffed with what he expected to be his country’s medical salvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Fred Jordan, Publisher of Taboo-Breaking Books, Dies at 95
description: At Grove Press, he and Barney Rosset challenged censors as they popularized D.H. Lawrence, Henry Miller, William S. Burroughs, Allen Ginsberg and others.
content: Fred Jordan, the publishing partner of Barney Rosset, whose groundbreaking Grove Press and Evergreen Review fended off government censors to introduce avant-garde authors who inspired the counterculture of the 1960s, died on April 19 in Brooklyn. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Edgar Sandoval
title: With 23 Candidates, Special Election in Texas Is Headed for Runoff
description: The front-runner was Susan Wright, who was endorsed by Donald J. Trump and is the widow of Representative Ron Wright, who died of Covid-19 in February.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Susan Wright, the Republican widow of a congressman who died of Covid-19, emerged on Saturday evening as the front-runner in a tight race to replace her husband in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Why Kristi Noem Is Rising Quickly as a Republican Prospect for 2024
description: Ms. Noem, the governor of South Dakota, has defied coronavirus restrictions and eagerly projects a rugged Great Plainswoman image. Her moves have stirred both support and conflict in the G.O.P.
content: PIERRE, S.D. — With Republicans hungry to cultivate their next generation of national leaders, it is not a Capitol Hill comer or a veteran battleground-state politician who is stirring interest by fusing Trumpism with a down-home conservatism spin. It is the first-term governor of South Dakota, Kristi Noem, a rancher who delights in sharing images of herself shooting pheasants and riding horses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Mitt Romney Is Booed by Members of His Own Party
description: Mr. Romney, a Utah Republican and an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump, was booed and heckled as he addressed the Utah Republican state convention on Saturday.
content: Senator Mitt Romney, the Utah Republican who is known for his outspoken criticism of former President Donald J. Trump, was booed and heckled by members of his own party as he spoke at the Utah Republican Party convention on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Danny Hakim and Mike McIntire
title: How the A.T.F., Key to Biden’s Gun Plan, Became an N.R.A. ‘Whipping Boy’
description: The federal agency tasked with enforcing gun laws has been hamstrung for years by the firearms lobby. Now, the president’s plan to rein in gun violence hinges on the A.T.F.’s success.
content: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — If there was one moment that summed up the current state of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, it was when the floor at the agency’s gun-tracing center caved in a couple of years ago under the weight of paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale, Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar, Sameer Yasir and Karan Deep Singh
title: India’s nightmare: Record high cases, vaccine shortages, hospital fires.
description: The country’s caseload remains higher than any other has ever reached.
content: It was supposed to be a day when India made a bold step forward in its fight against Covid-19, when everyone 18 and older in its vast population became eligible to be inoculated. Instead, several states reported that vaccine shortages had forced them to delay expanding access, and the country’s latest report of new cases remained higher than any other nation has ever reached.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Federal Money for Public Libraries
